Award.AwardTitle: iREU Site: Chemical Sciences in China
Award.AbstractNarration: This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE), with cofunding from the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE) and the Division of Materials Research (DMR), supports a new international Research Experiences for Undergraduates (iREU) site at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor (UM) and Peking University (PKU) in Beijing, China for the summers of 2008-2010. The program will be organized and managed by Brian Coppola, Associate Dean of the UM Department of Chemistry, with assistance from James Penner-Hahn, Associate Dean for Research in the Natural Sciences in the UM College of Literature, Science and Arts. The PKU Chemistry Department Vice Dean, Professor Li Zi-Chen, will serve as the in-department REU program coordinator in Beijing. Thirteen junior or senior undergraduates (10 supported by NSF and 3 supported by institutional funds) will travel to Beijing, China to participate in a ten-and-a-half week program in the Department of Chemistry at Peking University (PKU). During the first two-and-a-half weeks of the program, the U.S. REU students will participate in an intensive orientation to the Chinese language and culture, conducted mainly by immersion in Beijing. The students will spend the remaining eight weeks conducting independent research projects within PKU research groups. Peking University is the premiere research university in China and supports the traditional core areas of chemistry and interdisciplinary work in the chemical sciences. Over 50% of the chemistry faculty works in areas that overlap with other major areas of science including: Medicinal Chemistry, Materials Science & Engineering, Polymer Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Biological Chemistry, and the Life Sciences. This program is being set up as a bilateral exchange, using funding from the China side for its students to do research at UM. At the end of the ten-and-a-half week program, the U.S. REU students will participate in a joint, intercontinental electronic poster session with their Chinese counterparts who are working in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science and technology in China is undergoing dramatic change, perhaps greater than anywhere in the world, and it may be the most important country where exposing our future US scientists can have a profound effect on their careers.  Given the significant social differences between our countries, deep engagement by US undergraduates with the scientific and educational environments in China can help produce a cohort of students with an important scientific and cultural awareness of the emerging global community. Each summer, between 2008-2010, 13 students funded by NSF (plus about 12 others funded by U MIchigan), from around the United States, typically rising sophomores and juniors, comprised our International REU Site in the Chemical Sciences in China, which we established in 2007 as part of a bilateral exchange program. These REU students joined one of over 100 active research groups in China’s two premiere research institutions: Peking (PKU) and Tsinghua (THU) Universities, in Beijing.

The focus of this REU Site is the chemical sciences, which these two large chemistry departments cover both broadly and deeply. The program was organized and managed by faculty members from the departments of chemistry at UM, PKU, and THU, with help from the personnel at the UM-PKU Joint Institute. The US students joined an active cohort of over 350 undergraduate research students and 750 graduate students (from PKU & THU) in their 10-week program of research and professional development.  REU participants were recruited nationally, with an intentional, strategic emphasis on building a cohort that represents diverse backgrounds, settings, and experiences.  From 2008-2010, our REU Site in China hosted 62 undergraduate students (36 funded by NSF-REU, 2 by NSF-Noyce, 24 by UM) as full-fledged collaborators in the well-equipped settings of these major research universities, including access to large programs in chemical biology, polymer/materials, applied chemistry, and biomedical engineering. A two-stage orientation program facilitates the smooth transition of the REU students from the US into their Chinese research groups. Students participate in a US-based symposium of regional REU Sites via simulcast from China, which is a valuable culminating activity. To date, students from the 2008-10 group have had at least 6 publications and made 3 conference presentations from their research work in China.

The UM International REU Site has had numerous positive effects.  Our evaluation program, in which direct comparison with students in our domestic REU is done, shows that an immersive experience in an international research-active department results in higher gains in scientific independence, confidence for carrying out laboratory work, self-reliance, forming professional relationships, and in living with and communicating with people from diverse backgrounds. We are tracking our 36 NSF-REU students: to date, 3 are attending graduate school, 8 have their B.S. and are working or on a break before school, 4 are pursuing professional degrees, and 21 are still undergraduates.  We affirm the importance of diversifying the population of scientists: to date, 23/36 (64%) of our NSF-REU participants have been women, and 15/36 (42%) have been underrepresented minority students.
